metadata.case_name: Three Petitioners (residents of Amritsar) v. State of Punjab & Ors.

facts.text: The first Petitioner carries on a Bakery business in a shop in Bazar Jallianwala near Chowk Phowara of which he is a tenant.
The second Petitioner is the owner of a building consisting of a number of shops situated in Bazar Bikanarian.
The third Petitioner is a tenant in occupation of a residential house situated in Bazar Sodhian.
On 26th June 1962 the State Govt. declared by a Notification under Sec. 2(d) of the Act the entire area within the walled city of Amritsar to be a damaged area.
Two schemes: Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh sanctioned by State Govt. by Notification dated 17th July 1968; Ghantaghar Scheme sanctioned by Notification dated 10th October 1969.
Pursuant to Notifications, Notice issued on 26th November 1969 to first Petitioner to vacate premises covered by Chowk Phowara cum Jallianwala Bagh Scheme.

Notice given to Petitioners 2 and 3 in respect of buildings owned or occupied by them in Ghantaghar area Scheme, asking them to appear before Land Acquisition Collector (3rd Respondent) and explain interest in premises sought to be acquired.
Prior to partition, serious communal rioting in March 1947 in Amritsar caused extensive damage to property.
Punjab Damaged Areas Act 11 of 1947 passed on 9th May 1947 by Governor under Sec. 93, to cease on 15th August 1949.
East Punjab Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1949 enacted, embodying same provisions as 1947 Act.
Damaged Area Ordinance 16 of 1950 promulgated on 1st December 1950, replaced by Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act 10 of 1951.
Petitioners assured alternative accommodation: allotment of pacca shops in Dharam Singh Market (under construction at Rs. 26 lakhs), Ahata Bishan Dass ready; temporary in Kesribagh stalls.
Letter dated 6-1-1970 from Chairman Amritsar Improvement Trust assuring preference for oustees in shops at fixed rent.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sec. 2(d) offends Art. 14 as damaged area definition furnishes no guidelines, arbitrary, unguided, un-canalised and discriminatory.
Whether provisions regarding compensation are discriminatory because property can be acquired at discretion of Improvement Trust either under Punjab Town Improvement Act 1922 or under the Act.
Whether compensation provisions violate Art. 31(2) as it stood in 1951.
Whether acquisition under the Act is for public purpose as no contribution from Govt. or local authority.
Whether impugned Notifications sanctioning schemes void as power under Sec. 5 exhausted after sanctioning Dharam Singh Market Scheme.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sec. 2(d) offends Art. 14: no guidelines, arbitrary, enables picking and choosing areas, Notification vague.
Compensation provisions discriminatory: discretion to acquire under 1922 Act (advantageous) or this Act.
Compensation violates Art. 31(2) as stood in 1951.
Acquisition not for public purpose: no contribution from Govt. or local authority.
Notifications sanctioning schemes void: power under Sec. 5 exhausted after Dharam Singh Market.
Some buildings newly built or not damaged, restrictions unreasonable.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioners assured alternative accommodation in writing, preference in new shops.
Schemes beneficial, profit-sharing compensation not less than market value.

court_reasoning.text: Provisions reasonable, serve public interest for planned development; opportunity to object, compensation on profit-sharing basis minimum market value minus demolition costs, right to reference to Tribunal and appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test for reasonableness under Art. 19: nature of right, purpose, urgency balanced with social welfare.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination in Sec. 2(d): purpose clear from history (riots damage in Amritsar walled city), whole area notified, any part thereof damaged.
No option/discretion between Acts: Sec. 3 incorporates Sec. 28 of 1922 Act by reference, not alternative acquisition.
Compensation not illusory: similar to Land Acquisition Act, finalisation within reasonable time, assured alternative accommodation.
New/un-damaged buildings no impediment to scheme for public good.
No arguments on exhaustion of Sec. 5 power.

holdings.text: Act and schemes do not violate Arts. 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31(2); Sec. 2(d) valid.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines damaged area, schemes, acquisition, compensation computation as difference between scheme income and cost, minimum market value.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as violated by Act; held not.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Town Improvement Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Schemes provide for matters under this; incorporated by reference.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar definition of land, compensation principles.

outcome.summary: The petition challenging the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 and notifications as violative of Arts. 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31(2) dismissed; all contentions rejected.

key_quotes.text: The right of the individual has therefore to be sublimated to the larger interest of the general public.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balances individual rights under Art. 19 with social welfare.

key_quotes.text: the total compensation payable for any land acquired under this Act shall be the difference between- (a) the income of the Scheme... and (b) the cost of the scheme.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We cannot envisage a more reasonable and fair treatment accorded to the persons who have been displaced as a result of the Improvement Schemes.
key_quotes.speaker: court
